name: Reclaiming the archive
description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

key_work.title: Rodeo Baby!
key_work.brief_description:
“The artwork is centred upon the belief that it is our own bodies that are the truest archive of our experience and that any documentation is only ever an approximation of the person doing the gazing – not the gazed.”

While trawling archival video material, Jazz Money discovered an overwhelming amount of footage of First Peoples in rodeos. There was the joy of seeing Blak faces, but an unease in knowing non-Indigenous voyeurs likely captured the footage. In the vast network of archives in this country’s institutions, photos and videos of First Peoples are filed away, with the people who have been recorded – often unknowingly – and their descendants unaware the recordings exist.

Jazz reclaims these images, combining them with stills from film and TV, including “The Phantom Stockman” (1953), “Radiance” (1998) and” The Drover’s Wife” (2021), in this large-scale photographic essay. It celebrates First Peoples representation and the Aboriginal scholars who critique this colonial hoarding, giving new meaning to images that have been dislocated by archival practices. Jazz asks, “If these archival collections are the rodeo, who is playing cowboy with our images?”

constellations_primary.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_primary.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: Extraction
constellations_other.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

start.title: Rodeo Baby!
start.brief_description:

end.title: Radiance
end.brief_description: After the death of their mother, three estranged sisters return to their childhood home.

constellations_other.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_other.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: Rachel Perkins
constellations_other.description: The moving image has helped tell First Peoples stories through documentary, films and TV shows, with acclaimed director, producer and screenwriter Rachel Perkins contributing significantly to these stories.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

links.description: Jazz Money’s Rodeo Baby! reclaims images of First Peoples from screen archives. One such image is from Rachel Perkins’ film Radiance, which depicts a scene when the three female leads burn down their family home.

start.title: Shadow of the Boomerang
start.brief_description: An American brother and sister move to Australia to manage a cattle station, but the brother’s racist attitude causes problems. After hearing a message by evangelist Billy Graham on the radio though, he has a change of heart and learns to accept the Aboriginal people.

constellations_other.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_other.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_other.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

links.description: Yorta Yorta man Jimmy Little wrote and performed the song “Shadow of the Boomerang” for the film of the same name. In the film, Jimmy’s performance of the song was a catalyst in changing the heart of the racist protagonist.

start.title: The Drover's Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson
start.brief_description: Country is a character in this revisionist western from Leah Purcell, based on Henry Lawson’s short story, The Drover’s Wife (1892).

constellations_other.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_other.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: The ‘Australian' alps
constellations_other.description: These feature films and documentaries show how stories have been told to lay claim - and reclaim - the land and our national identity.

constellations_other.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_other.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

end.title: Shadow of the Boomerang
end.brief_description: An American brother and sister move to Australia to manage a cattle station, but the brother’s racist attitude causes problems. After hearing a message by evangelist Billy Graham on the radio though, he has a change of heart and learns to accept the Aboriginal people.

constellations_other.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_other.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

links.description: Leah Purcell’s film is a Blak Western set in the 19th century in the high country. Shadow of the Boomerang is a Christian Western shot in the outback that depicts racist views of cattle station owners toward Aboriginal people.

start.title: Radiance
start.brief_description: After the death of their mother, three estranged sisters return to their childhood home.

constellations_other.name: Reclaiming the archive
constellations_other.description: Applying an Indigenous lens on Australia’s film and television archives.

constellations_other.name: The ‘Australian' alps
constellations_other.description: These feature films and documentaries show how stories have been told to lay claim - and reclaim - the land and our national identity.

constellations_other.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_other.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.

links.description: Radiance portrays the power and resilience of Aboriginal women. Leah Purcell tells a story of Aboriginal women’s strength in her directorial debut The Drover’s Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson. Both films began as stage plays and were transformed for the screen.
